message.content:
cs.CL, cs.AI, cs.LG, cs.NE, cs.IR. 

This paper deals with stylometry and deep learning methods for style imitation, which are commonly studied in the natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) communities. Therefore, cs.CL (Computation and Language) is the most likely sub-category. The paper also proposes a new approach based on the combinatorial application of multiple paraphrasing techniques, which involves optimization and search algorithms, and can be considered as an AI (Artificial Intelligence) problem. Hence, cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) is the second likely sub-category. The paper evaluates the proposed approach on several datasets and compares it with state-of-the-art methods, which involves statistical analysis and experimental design, and can be categorized as a machine learning (ML) problem. Therefore, cs.LG (Machine Learning) and cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing) are also likely sub-categories. Finally, the paper discusses the implications of the proposed approach for author profiling and text classification, which are common topics in information retrieval (IR) and text mining. Hence, cs.IR (Information Retrieval) is also a likely sub-category.
